results.question: What is the energy source share distribution?

request.transcript: What is the energy source share distribution?

response.voice_response: In November 2024, energy use was distributed with HVAC at 43%, production at 33%, lighting at 10%, compressed air at 9%, and UPS/IT at 5%. By December 2024, the distribution shifted slightly: HVAC increased to 44%, production decreased to 31%, lighting rose to 13%, compressed air fell to 8%, and UPS/IT dropped to 4%. In April 2024, it was HVAC at 43%, production at 34%, lighting at 12%, compressed air at 5%, and UPS/IT at 5%.

results.question: What maintenance records do we have for pump 1?

request.transcript: What maintenance records do we have for pump 1?

response.voice_response: For Chilled Water Primary Pump 1 (PMP-CHWP-01), there are two maintenance records. The first is quarterly preventive maintenance by Sunil Sharma, which included checking gland packing and greasing bearings. The second is an annual overhaul by Nikhil Mehta, where the mechanical seal and wear rings were replaced. Additionally, for Hot Water Pump 1 (PMP-HTWP-01), quarterly preventive maintenance was performed by Santosh Pillai, involving similar tasks like adjusting gland packing and greasing bearings. No records are available specifically for Sump Pump Pump 1 or Transfer Pump Pump 1 under the term "pump 1."

operational_docs.title: Energy Meter Calibration Verification
operational_docs.content: Energy Meter Calibration Verification | Type: sop | Procedure for verifying energy meter calibration accuracy using reference standard. Equipment: Reference class 0.1 portable meter, CT test leads, current clamp. 1) Connect reference meter in parallel with meter under test. 2) Measure for minimum 15-minute interval at stable load. 3) Compare kWh readings: Error % = (Test - Reference) / Reference × 100. 4) Acceptable accuracy: Class 0.2S: ±0.2%, Class 0.5S: ±0.5%, Class 1.0: ±1.0%. 5) If outside tolerance: check CT connections, PT ratio, meter programming. 6) Re-program if necessary. Repeat verification. 7) Record results in calibration certificate. Next verification: 12 months.

results.question: Show me the energy balance with losses

request.transcript: Show me the energy balance with losses

response.voice_response: The total grid imports for August 2024 were 662,497 kWh, and for December 2024, they were 649,279 kWh. Losses can be inferred from discrepancies between consumption categories and total imports. In August, the energy breakdown adds up to approximately 702,498 kWh (sum of HVAC, production, lighting, compressed air, UPS/IT), indicating potential losses or unaccounted usage around 40,001 kWh. Similarly, for December, with a total of 701,279 kWh in categories and 649,279 kWh imported, there's an approximate shortfall or loss of about 52,000 kWh. These figures suggest inefficiencies or measurement variances contributing to the energy balance discrepancies.

results.question: Compare EB vs DG vs solar power sources

request.transcript: Compare EB vs DG vs solar power sources

response.voice_response:
I currently have data on diesel generators and energy meters but not directly on emergency backup (EB) or solar power sources. Here’s what I can tell you:

For diesel generators at the utility building, we have several running: DG-01 with 91% health and a current load of 40.1%, DG-05 with 96% health, and DG-03 also at 96% health with a 55.7% load. These are critical for emergency power.

Regarding energy meters in the Main Plant, EM-DG_-052 has the highest health score at 99%, while EM-DG_-087 is at 94%. Both support monitoring plant energy usage.

For detailed comparisons involving solar power or specific EB systems, I would need more data on those sources. Let me know if you have additional information or need help with something else!

operational_docs.title: Energy Meter Calibration Verification
operational_docs.content: Energy Meter Calibration Verification | Type: sop | Procedure for verifying energy meter calibration accuracy using reference standard. Equipment: Reference class 0.1 portable meter, CT test leads, current clamp. 1) Connect reference meter in parallel with meter under test. 2) Measure for minimum 15-minute interval at stable load. 3) Compare kWh readings: Error % = (Test - Reference) / Reference × 100. 4) Acceptable accuracy: Class 0.2S: ±0.2%, Class 0.5S: ±0.5%, Class 1.0: ±1.0%. 5) If outside tolerance: check CT connections, PT ratio, meter programming. 6) Re-program if necessary. Repeat verification. 7) Record results in calibration certificate. Next verification: 12 months.

operational_docs.title: Energy Audit Report — November 2025
operational_docs.content:
Energy Audit Report — November 2025 | Type: energy_audit | Monthly energy consumption report for November 2025. Total Grid Import: 424,883 kWh. Peak Demand: 1,934 kW (Contract: 3000 kW). Average Power Factor: 0.89. DG Run Hours: 29 hours. DG Fuel Consumed: 3,560 liters. 
Breakdown: HVAC 41% (176,242 kWh), Production 25% (107,258 kWh), Lighting 12% (49,047 kWh), Compressed Air 9% (37,743 kWh), UPS/IT 13% (54,594 kWh). EPI: 108.8 kWh/sq.ft/year. HVAC kW/TR: 1.22. Savings identified: VFD on AHU fans (15,053 kWh/month), Chiller sequencing optimization (3,005 kWh/month), Compressed air leak repair (3,721 kWh/month).

operational_docs.title: Energy Audit Report — August 2025
operational_docs.content:
Energy Audit Report — August 2025 | Type: energy_audit | Monthly energy consumption report for August 2025. Total Grid Import: 699,358 kWh. Peak Demand: 2,442 kW (Contract: 3000 kW). Average Power Factor: 0.91. DG Run Hours: 36 hours. DG Fuel Consumed: 4,340 liters. 
Breakdown: HVAC 44% (309,848 kWh), Production 28% (197,977 kWh), Lighting 13% (87,859 kWh), Compressed Air 7% (49,124 kWh), UPS/IT 8% (54,550 kWh). EPI: 114.7 kWh/sq.ft/year. HVAC kW/TR: 1.09. Savings identified: VFD on AHU fans (7,131 kWh/month), Chiller sequencing optimization (5,203 kWh/month), Compressed air leak repair (6,770 kWh/month).

data.llm_response: There are harmonic issues indicated by high neutral currents at multiple distribution boards. Specifically, Distribution Board 32 on Block B First Floor reports a neutral current of 102.6 A against a threshold of 40 A. Similarly, DB-UT-B18 in the Utility Building Basement has a neutral current of 118.8 A, and DB-MA-G04 on Main Plant Ground Floor records 53.0 A, both exceeding their thresholds. These alerts suggest possible harmonics, but no specific Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) violations are listed here.

operational_docs.title: DG Set Emergency Start Procedure
operational_docs.content: DG Set Emergency Start Procedure | Type: sop | Procedure for emergency manual start of diesel generator sets when AMF (Auto Mains Failure) panel fails. 1) Verify mains supply is indeed lost — check incomer breaker status. 2) At DG control panel, select 'LOCAL' mode. 3) Check engine oil pressure gauge — should be zero (engine off). 4) Check coolant level in expansion tank. 5) Ensure fuel isolation valve is OPEN. 6) Press START button — hold for maximum 10 seconds. 7) If engine does not start, wait 30 seconds before retry. Maximum 3 attempts. 8) Once running, check: RPM 1500 ±1%, voltage 415V ±5%, frequency 50 Hz ±0.5%. 9) Close DG output breaker. 10) Transfer load using changeover switch. CAUTION: Never parallel DG with mains without synchronization equipment.

results.question: Show me everything about the electrical system including alerts and maintenance

request.transcript: Show me everything about the electrical system including alerts and maintenance

response.voice_response:
In the Main Plant, Feeder 76 is running with an 88% health score, while Main Incomer Meter 4 is critical at 100% health. Feeder 66 is on standby at 85%. In Block B, Feeder 70 is under maintenance at 87% health. Utility Building has Feeders 32 in standby (80%), 99 offline (100%), and 16 under maintenance (94%). Alerts for low-severity maintenance include inspections of capacitor banks linked to APFC-2 and Distribution Boards 28 and 3.

Recent corrective maintenance involved emergency repairs on Sub Meter 46, Feeder 99, and Sub Meter 19 by technicians Amit Tiwari, Kiran Reddy, and Vikram Patel. Incident reports detail tripping issues with Feeders 93 and 69 due to loose connections, resulting in downtime of 22.5 and 4.3 hours respectively.

Routine inspection on Feeder 66 found no immediate issues. Further inspections are recommended for similar equipment.

In Block A, Feeder 89 has a fault but perfect health. Alerts include due capacitor bank inspections for Auto Power Factor Panel 2 and two Distribution Boards at the Main Plant; these have low severity. results.question: I need a full overview of pump 1 with trends, alerts, and work orders

request.transcript: I need a full overview of pump 1 with trends, alerts, and work orders

response.voice_response:
For Sump Pump Pump 1 (PMP-SUMP-01), it is currently offline in the warehouse with a health score of 97% but high criticality. There's an alert for a coupling alignment check due; however, no power consumption or flow rate data are available as it’s not running.

Hot Water Pump 1 (PMP-HTWP-01) is running in the pump room, has a lower health score at 58%, and also requires attention with a work order for predictive maintenance, though it was cancelled awaiting vendor availability. There's no power consumption currently logged.

results.question: What is going on with the HVAC system? Show energy, alerts, and maintenance

request.transcript: What is going on with the HVAC system? Show energy, alerts, and maintenance

response.voice_response: Currently, Chiller 3 in the utility building has a fault status due to condenser tube cleaning needs; its efficiency is dropping, marked as medium severity. The chiller's health score is at 69%, with a criticality rating of critical. In April 2024, HVAC accounted for 43% of energy consumption, totaling 259,642 kWh. Energy savings opportunities include VFD optimization on AHU fans and chiller sequencing. Two recent alerts: refrigerant leak tests are due for Package Chillers 9 and 11. Maintenance reports indicate an emergency breakdown repair was conducted at the Motor Control Center 1-HVAC by technicians Vijay Rao and Ravi Shankar, with no immediate actions required following Chiller 8's inspection showing slight vibration increases.

data.llm_response:
The HVAC system has experienced an emergency breakdown at Motor Control Center 1-HVAC, which was rectified by technicians Vijay Rao and Ravi Shankar after identifying and fixing the root cause. Currently, Chiller 3 in the utility building is reporting a fault with medium severity due to efficiency dropping from condenser tube issues; it has a health score of 69% and is operating at 48.3% load consuming 163.2 kW.

Energy-wise, for April 2024, HVAC consumed 43% of total energy or 259,642 kWh. Savings were identified through VFD on AHU fans (7,192 kWh/month) and chiller sequencing optimization (4,830 kWh/month). Alerts are pending refrigerant leak tests for Package Chillers 9 and 11.

Chiller 8 is under maintenance with a slight vibration increase but no immediate action needed; it's operating at 50.3% load using 382.9 kW. The system is stable, yet monitoring is advised due to these incidents.
